definition:
Let $C$ be a $(n,k,d)$-code over ${\mathbb}{F}_q$.

The *packing radius* of $C$ is defined to be the value $$\begin{aligned}
\rho(C)=\frac{d-1}{2}.\end{aligned}$$

The *covering radius* of $C$ is $$\begin{aligned}
r(C)=\max_x\min_c \delta(x,c)\end{aligned}$$ with
$x\in {\mathbb}{F}_q^n$ and $c\in C$, and where $\delta$ denotes the
Hamming distance on ${\mathbb}{F}_q^n$.

The $C$ is said to be *perfect* if $r(C)=\rho(C)$.

The list of of linear perfect codes is very short, including only
trivial codes, Hamming codes (i.e. $\rho=1$), and the binary and ternary
codes.
